title: 108_hr4747
content: The Act may be cited as the "Dietary Supplement Regulatory Implementation Act of 2004". The Congress finds that over 158 million Americans use dietary supplements to improve their health, with consumer spending reaching $17.1 billion in 2000. The FDA predicts continued growth in supplement use due to factors like aging populations and advances in science. The Dietary Supplement Health and Education Act of 1994 ensures consumer access to supplements and promotes scientific research. DSHEA, enacted in 1994, regulates dietary supplements by requiring truthful, non-misleading claims on labels, setting manufacturing standards, and treating supplements like foods, not drugs. Manufacturers must submit adequate information for regulatory purposes. DSHEA requires manufacturers to provide safety information for new ingredients in dietary supplements before selling them. The FDA has powers to remove unsafe supplements from the market, and the Office of Dietary Supplements was created to expand research and consumer information. However, the FDA has not effectively enforced DSHEA and needs more resources for implementation. Congress has allocated additional funds to enforce DSHEA, reaching $9,700,000 in fiscal year 2003. The FDA asserts that between $24,000,000 and $65,000,000 per year will be needed to fully implement DSHEA. SEC. 3. AUTHORIZATION AND APPROPRIATION OF RESOURCES. Authorization of appropriations for the Dietary Supplement Health and Education Act of 1994 and regulatory requirements under the Federal Food, Drug, and Cosmetic Act are as follows: $30,000,000 for fiscal year 2006, $40,000,000 for fiscal year 2007, $50,000,000 for fiscal year 2008, $65,000,000 for fiscal year 2009, and $20,000,000 for fiscal year 2005. The Office of Dietary Supplements at the National Institutes of Health is authorized to receive funds for research and development of consumer information on dietary supplements. $30,000,000 is appropriated for fiscal year 2005, with additional sums authorized for fiscal years 2006 through 2009. The National Institutes of Health allocated $30,000,000 for fiscal year 2005 to regulate dietary supplements. The Secretary of Health and Human Services is responsible for using the funds appropriately. SEC. 4. ANNUAL ACCOUNTABILITY REPORT ON THE REGULATION OF DIETARY SUPPLEMENTS. The Secretary must submit an annual report to Congress on the implementation and enforcement of the Dietary Supplement Health and Education Act of 1994. The report includes details on funding and personnel dedicated to dietary supplement regulation and adverse event reporting systems within the Food and Drug Administration. The annual report to Congress includes details on funding and personnel dedicated to enforcement of dietary supplement labeling, good manufacturing practices inspections, and new ingredient reviews by the Food and Drug Administration. It also summarizes the number of inspections and enforcement actions taken. The annual report to Congress includes details on enforcement actions related to dietary supplements by the Food and Drug Administration and the Department of Health and Human Services. It covers the number of claims requested for substantiation, false claims identified, and research activities supported by the Office of Dietary Supplements. Recommendations for administrative or legislative actions are also included. The annual report to Congress includes details on enforcement actions related to dietary supplements by the FDA and HHS, including recommendations for administrative or legislative actions. Additionally, any other relevant information regarding dietary supplement regulation determined appropriate by the Secretary is also included. SEC. 5. Dietary supplements containing ephedrine alkaloids. The Congress acknowledges the risk of illness or injury posed by dietary supplements containing ephedrine alkaloids and grants the Secretary authority to remove such supplements from the market. If the Secretary determines a significant risk, all supplements with ephedrine alkaloids should be declared adulterated. The Congress grants the Secretary authority to remove dietary supplements with ephedrine alkaloids from the market if a significant risk is determined. It is recommended that botanical sources of ephedrine alkaloids remain available in unaltered forms, marketed at traditional dosages, and labeled only for traditional uses. SEC. 6. EDUCATION PROGRAMS REGARDING DIETARY SUPPLEMENTS. The Secretary will implement education programs for health care professionals and consumers on the safety, health benefits, and potential interactions of dietary supplements. $5,000,000 is authorized for fiscal year 2005 for health professional education. Public education forums, advertisements, and the Internet will be used to educate consumers. Authorization of $5,000,000 for public education forums, advertisements, and the Internet in fiscal year 2005. The Secretary will establish a system for reporting serious adverse experiences related to dietary supplements. The term "Secretary" refers to the Secretary of Health and Human Services.
